coatOfArms.name: Halifax UK
coatOfArms.description: The coat of arms features a golden lion rampant symbolizing courage and strength, flanked by golden wheat sheaves representing agriculture and fertility. The blue and silver colors represent loyalty and peace respectively.

coatOfArms.name: Halifax,UK
coatOfArms.description: The coat of arms features a golden lion rampant symbolizing courage and strength, flanked by golden wheat sheaves representing agriculture and fertility. The blue and silver colors represent loyalty and peace respectively.

coatOfArms.name: Prague
coatOfArms.description: The coat of arms displays a silver castle on a red shield, symbolizing the city’s fortitude and history. The golden crowned lion, the symbol of Bohemia, acts as a supporter, emphasizing royal heritage.

coatOfArms.name: New York City

motto.english: Seal of the City of New York

coatOfArms.description: The coat of arms of New York City features a shield supported by a sailor and a Native American, symbolizing unity and history. An eagle crest represents strength and independence.

coatOfArms.name: New York

motto.english: Seal of the City of New York

coatOfArms.description: The coat of arms of New York City features a shield supported by a sailor and a Native American, symbolizing unity and history. An eagle crest represents strength and independence.

coatOfArms.name: Los Angeles
coatOfArms.description: seat of Los Angeles County, and largest city in California, United States

coatOfArms.name: Alexandria
coatOfArms.description: Alexandria is a major city in Egypt. Lying at the western edge of the Nile River Delta

coatOfArms.name: Bern
coatOfArms.description: city in Switzerland, capital of the canton of Bern and de facto capital of Switzerland

coatOfArms.name: Warsaw
coatOfArms.description: The metropolis stands on the River Vistula in east-central Poland. Its population is officially estimated at 1.86 million residents within a greater metropolitan area of 3.27 million residents, which makes Warsaw the 6th most-populous city in the European Union.

coatOfArms.name: switzerland
coatOfArms.description: The triangular shield shape was frequently used by the federal administration throughout the 20th century, and adopted officially (as emblem of the federal administration, not necessarily as emblem of Switzerland as sovereign entity) in 2017. Precedents for this shield shape go back to designs dated to as early as 1815. The official coat of arms of the Swiss Confederation is a white couped cross in a red heraldic shield, without explicit specification of the shape of the shield, and a variety of shield shapes are in use.

coatOfArms.name: Lower Silesian Voivodeship
coatOfArms.description: The design of the coat of arms had been for the first time used by Henry II the Pious, duke of Wrocław and Greater Poland, and the High Duke of Poland. It was present in his seal, that was used from 1224 to 1240. It depicted an eagle with a crescent put across its wings, with a cross pattée on top of it, in its middle, placed on a shield. Such design was inspired by the seal used by Henry the Bearded, his father. Since then, the black eagle with a white (silver) crescent put across its wings, usually with a white (silver) cross pattée on top of it, placed in the yellow (golden) escutcheon (shield), had become the symbol of the Lower Silesia, including being the symbol of the Piast rulers of the Duchy of Silesia, and many of its successors

coatOfArms.name: Lusatia
coatOfArms.description: The history behind Lusatian coats of arms is deeply intertwined with the region's cultural and political identity. The coat of arms with an ox, which may have been for Lusatia, first appeared in the time of Henry IV of Meissen. It is believed to have been the arms of Henry IV for Lusatia, as it was used in the coat of arms of the Benedictine monastery of Göss, which dates back to the time of King Přemysl Ottokar II the Great. The idea of the ox as the emblem of Lusatia was also put forward around 1520 in George Spalatin's Saxon chronicles.

usage.name: London
usage.description: The coat of arms is not just a decorative symbol; it represents the sovereignty and independence of the City of London. It is used in various official capacities, including on documents, buildings, and ceremonial occasions. The arms are also present in stained glass, street furniture, and other public displays throughout the city, reinforcing the identity and heritage of London.
